nodes.label: Case

id.description: Unique internal identifier for the node, used for stable references.

source.description: The origin of the data (e.g., 'Supreme Court Website', 'BDLII Scraper v2.1').

extracted_at.description: ISO 8601 timestamp of when the data was ingested or last scraped.

extracted_by.description: Identifier for the process or user that performed the extraction (e.g., 'daily_ingestion_job').

confidence_score.description: A score from 0.0 to 1.0 indicating the confidence in the accuracy of the extracted text and metadata (e.g., from an OCR or parsing process).

version.description: An integer that increments with each significant update to the node's data.

created_at.description: ISO 8601 timestamp of when this node was first created in the graph.

updated_at.description: ISO 8601 timestamp of the last modification to this node.

changelog.description: A human-readable log of changes made in each version, e.g., ['v2: Corrected judgment date', 'v3: Added full text URL'].

trust_score.description: A composite score reflecting the overall trustworthiness of the case, calculated from authority_level, verification_status, and citation_count.

authority_level.description: The hierarchical level of the court, indicating its judicial authority.

citation_count.description: A dynamically updated count of how many other documents in the graph cite this case.

verification_status.description: The verification state of the node's content.

nodes.description: Represents a single legal case or judgment. The 'citation' (e.g., '55 DLR (AD) 130') serves as the unique identifier. 'case_type' could be Civil, Criminal, Writ, etc.

nodes.label: Statute
nodes.description: Represents a legislative act, ordinance, or code, such as 'The Code of Civil Procedure, 1908'. 'type' can be 'Act', 'Ordinance', 'Rules', 'Order'.

nodes.label: Section

id.description: Unique internal identifier for the node, used for stable references.

source.description: The origin of the data (e.g., 'http://bdlaws.minlaw.gov.bd/', 'Legislation Scraper v1.0').

extracted_at.description: ISO 8601 timestamp of when the data was ingested or last scraped.

extracted_by.description: Identifier for the process or user that performed the extraction.

confidence_score.description: A score indicating confidence in the accuracy of the extracted statutory text.

version.description: An integer that increments with each amendment or correction to the section's text.

created_at.description: ISO 8601 timestamp of when this node was first created.

updated_at.description: ISO 8601 timestamp of the last modification.

changelog.description: A log of changes, e.g., ['v2: Amended by Act No. 5 of 2023'].

trust_score.description: A composite score reflecting the trustworthiness of the section, based on source authority and verification.

authority_level.description: The hierarchical level of the legal instrument.

citation_count.description: A dynamically updated count of how many documents cite this section.

verification_status.description: The verification state of the section's content.

nodes.description: A specific section within a Statute. 'section_number' can accommodate complex numbering like '151A'.

nodes.label: Judge
nodes.description: Represents a judge who heard or authored a case. 'judge_id' is a unique internal identifier.

nodes.label: Court
nodes.description: Represents a court of law. 'level' can be 'Appellate Division', 'High Court Division', 'District Court', etc. 'name' is the full official name.

nodes.label: Party
nodes.description: A litigant in a case (an individual, corporation, or state entity). 'type' can be 'Person', 'Corporation', 'Government'.

nodes.label: Principle
nodes.description: An abstract legal principle established or discussed in a case (e.g., 'Natural Justice'). This node allows for thematic analysis across cases.

nodes.label: Doctrine
nodes.description: A well-established legal doctrine, often with a formal name (e.g., 'Res Judicata', 'Lis Pendens'). More formal than a Principle.

nodes.label: Holding
nodes.description: The specific, binding ruling of a court on a particular point of law or issue raised in the case. A case can have multiple holdings. 'holding_id' is a unique identifier.

nodes.label: Appeal
nodes.description: Represents the procedural event of an appeal being filed. This node connects the lower court case with the appellate court case and stores metadata about the appeal itself.

nodes.label: Motion
nodes.description: A formal request made to a court for an order or ruling during a case, e.g., a motion for injunction or bail.

nodes.label: Part
nodes.description: A structural division of a Statute, such as 'Part X' of the Code of Civil Procedure.

nodes.label: Order
nodes.description: A structural division, particularly relevant for procedural codes like the CPC, e.g., 'Order XLI'.

nodes.label: Rule
nodes.description: A specific rule within an Order of a procedural code, e.g., 'Rule 1' of 'Order XLI'.

nodes.label: Definition
nodes.description: A specific definition provided within a Statute.

nodes.label: CaseVersion
nodes.description: Represents a specific publication of a case (e.g., in DLR, BLD, MLR). This allows multiple citations to resolve to a single canonical 'Case' node.

nodes.label: Amendment
nodes.description: Represents a specific legislative amendment to a Statute or its components.

nodes.label: ChangeLog
nodes.description: A generic node for tracking metadata about changes to any node in the graph, for data governance and versioning.

nodes.label: Jurisdiction
nodes.description: Represents a legal jurisdiction, e.g., 'Bangladesh', 'India', 'Pakistan', 'UK'. Essential for handling cross-jurisdictional citations.

nodes.label: Chunk
nodes.description: A small, semantically coherent segment of text from a parent document (e.g., a Case or a long Section), optimized for vector retrieval. It holds its own embedding and various metadata fields used during the RAG pipeline for scoring, ranking, and final context assembly. 'chunk_id' is a unique identifier (e.g., UUID).

relationships.description: Connects a case to a precedent it cites. 'cited_for' explains the legal point for which the precedent was referenced.
A strong, negative citation where a higher or later court explicitly overturns a previous decision, rendering it bad law.
Connects an appellate court decision to the lower court decision it upholds.
A case acknowledges a precedent but explains why it does not apply due to different facts or legal issues.
A generic structural relationship. Connects a component (Section, Part, Order, Rule) to its parent Statute or parent component (e.g., Rule -> Order).
Assigns a Statute to its sovereign Jurisdiction.
Connects a case to a specific statutory Section it analyzes, interprets, or applies.
A specific structural relationship connecting a Statute to its main Parts.
Connects a case to the judges on the bench. 'role' can be 'Author', 'Member', 'Chief Justice'.
Indicates which court heard and decided a particular case.
Identifies a party as the petitioner or appellant in a case.
Identifies a party as the respondent in a case.
Connects an Amendment Act to the specific Section it alters. 'change_type' can be 'Substitution', 'Insertion', 'Omission'.
Connects a new version of a Section to the old version it replaces.
Links a specific published version of a case to the canonical abstract Case node.
Connects an appellate decision (from) to the lower court decision it is an appeal of (to). 'outcome' can be 'Affirmed', 'Reversed', 'Remanded'.
Connects a case to its specific legal holdings.
Connects a landmark case to a legal principle it helps to establish or define.

Connects a text chunk to its parent source document. The 'to' node can be a Case or a Section, providing a direct link for context retrieval. 'position' indicates the chunk's sequential order in the source document.
Indicates that a specific chunk of text mentions or refers to a statutory Section. This is more granular than the case-level APPLIES_SECTION, pinpointing the exact location of the reference.
Connects a case to a precedent it cites. 'cited_for' explains the legal point for which the precedent was referenced. This is the renamed CITES_PRECEDENT relationship.
A highly granular relationship indicating that a specific chunk of text from one case cites another case. This is crucial for providing the exact textual context of a citation during retrieval.

indexes.name: case_jurisdiction_date_type_idx
indexes.description: Optimizes queries filtering cases by jurisdiction, then date, then type. Supports efficient chronological lookups within a specific jurisdiction and case category.

indexes.name: case_jurisdiction_year_idx
indexes.description: A broader index for quickly finding all cases within a jurisdiction for a given year. Supports high-level trend analysis and filtering.

indexes.name: section_statute_part_number_idx
indexes.description: Enables rapid lookup of specific statutory sections when the statute, part, and section number are known. Critical for precise legal referencing.

indexes.name: case_embedding_index
indexes.description: For case-level semantic search. Finds cases with similar overall legal concepts or summaries.

indexes.name: section_embedding_index
indexes.description: For section-level semantic search. Enables finding relevant laws and statutes based on conceptual queries.

indexes.name: chunk_embedding_index
indexes.description: Primary index for RAG. Facilitates fine-grained semantic search over the entire text corpus to find the most relevant snippets of text.

indexes.name: case_fulltext_idx
indexes.description: Supports keyword-based searches across the main textual content of cases.

indexes.name: section_fulltext_idx
indexes.description: Supports keyword-based searches across the title and text of statutory sections.

indexes.name: case_citation_constraint
indexes.description: Ensures uniqueness and provides fastest possible lookup for a Case by its citation. This is a unique property constraint, which includes an index.

indexes.name: section_id_constraint
indexes.description: Ensures uniqueness and provides fastest possible lookup for a Section by its internal ID. This is a unique property constraint.

indexes.name: case_trust_score_idx
indexes.description: Optimizes sorting and filtering cases by their trust_score, allowing for quick retrieval of high-authority cases.

indexes.name: case_year_idx
indexes.description: Optimizes queries that filter or range on year alone, complementing the composite indexes.

indexes.name: chunk_embedding_index
indexes.description: Index for fast semantic search over all text chunks. This is the primary index for fine-grained retrieval.

indexes.name: case_embedding_index
indexes.description: Index for case-level embeddings. Useful for finding relevant cases based on a query about the overall topic or summary.

indexes.name: section_embedding_index
indexes.description: Index for section-level embeddings. Enables direct semantic search for relevant laws and statutory provisions.

constraints.description: This is conceptually enforced by ensuring relationships (e.g., CITES, CHUNK_OF) only connect to nodes with existing 'id' properties. The graph database engine typically handles this by disallowing the creation of relationships to non-existent nodes.

rag_configuration.retrieval_strategy: Multi-granularity hybrid retrieval. Start with chunk-level vector search, then expand context by traversing CHUNK_OF, CITES_IN_CHUNK, and REFERENCES relationships to gather parent document info, cited cases, and referenced statutes. Use case-level and section-level embeddings for broader, initial filtering or query expansion.
